message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The retinal hemorrhages and lethargy suggest that the most likely cause of the symptoms is abusive head trauma (AHT). A noncontrast CT scan of the head in cases of AHT typically shows a crescent-shaped hematoma due to subdural hemorrhage. Options B, C, and D are not typically seen in cases of AHT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's lethargy and retinal hemorrhages suggest non-accidental trauma, specifically shaken baby syndrome. Noncontrast CT scans of the head typically show crescent-shaped hematomas in these cases. The other options listed are not typically associated with shaken baby syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with lethargy and retinal hemorrhages, which suggest shaken baby syndrome. The most likely finding on a noncontrast CT scan of the head is a crescent-shaped hematoma, which is characteristic of subdural hematoma. Lens-shaped hematoma is characteristic of epidural hematoma, but it is less common in shaken baby syndrome. Blood in the basal cisterns and multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts are not typical findings in shaken baby syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The key findings of lethargy and retinal hemorrhages suggest shaken baby syndrome, and the most likely finding on a noncontrast CT head would be a crescent-shaped hematoma, which is a characteristic finding in shaken baby syndrome. Lens-shaped hematoma is seen in epidural hematomas. Blood in the basal cisterns suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is not commonly associated with shaken baby syndrome. Multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts are not commonly seen in shaken baby syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest non-accidental trauma, specifically shaken baby syndrome. Retinal hemorrhages are a common finding in this condition. A noncontrast CT scan of the head would likely show a crescent-shaped hematoma, which is characteristic of subdural hematoma, a common finding in shaken baby syndrome. Lens-shaped hematoma is characteristic of epidural hematoma, which is less common in this population. Blood in the basal cisterns and multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts are less likely to be seen in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s lethargy and retinal hemorrhages suggest that the most likely diagnosis is shaken baby syndrome. The most likely finding on a noncontrast CT scan of the head is a crescent-shaped hematoma, typically found over the cerebral convexities or interhemispheric fissure. The other options are less likely or not associated with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lethargic appearance and retinal hemorrhages suggest non-accidental trauma or shaken baby syndrome. A crescent-shaped hematoma is the most likely finding on a noncontrast CT scan of the head due to the subdural hematoma. Lens-shaped hematoma is associated with epidural hematoma, blood in the basal cisterns indicates subarachnoid hemorrhage, and multiple cortical and subcortical infarcts suggest ischemic stroke, none of which are likely in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including lethargy and retinal hemorrhages, suggest the diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome. This can cause subdural hematoma, which would appear as a crescent-shaped hematoma on a CT scan of the head. The other answer choices are not typically associated with shaken baby syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and ophthalmologic examination findings suggest shaken baby syndrome. On a noncontrast CT scan of the head, a crescent-shaped hematoma is the most common finding in shaken baby syndrome. The other options are not typically seen in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and past medical history are suggestive of abusive head trauma. Retinal hemorrhages and a non-awake patient are red flags for abusive head trauma. A crescent-shaped hematoma is most commonly seen on a noncontrast CT scan in cases of abusive head trauma. Other options are less likely to be seen in this scenario.
